Award.AwardTitle: International Workshop on Numerical Modeling of Earthquake Motions: Waves and Ruptures, Smolenice, Slovakia June 30-July 4, 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a travel award to promote participation in the Numerical modeling of earthquake motions: waves and ruptures workshop in Slovakia hosted by the Solvak Academy of Sciences. Earthquake rupture dynamics and ground motion simulation are central to seismology and earthquake engineering. Much excellent earthquake-source-related research occurs in Europe, Asia, and the rest of the world. International scientific exchange serves to enhance productivity and excellence, as well as train the next generation of seismologists and experts in earthquake source processes and computational seismology. Funding in this travel proposal will support approximately 24 U.S. students, early career scientists, and members of underrepresented groups.

Ground motion simulation and, more recently, dynamic rupture modeling are at the heart of seismic hazard calculations and studies of earthquake source processes. A wide range of numerical methods are being used, and there are growing efforts to perform verification and validation of the simulation codes. In addition, researchers are now routinely performing dynamic rupture simulations of actual earthquakes and slow slip events, addressing questions about how ruptures navigate fault geometric complexities; the role of friction, pore fluid pressure, inelastic material response, and dynamic weakening mechanisms on rupture nucleation, propagation, and arrest; etc. This international workshop will bring together modelers from different countries with observational seismologists and experimentalists, facilitating exchange of scientific knowledge and ideas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided travel support for US scientists to attend an international workshop on earthquake source processes and seismic wave propagation. Topics within the scope of the meeting include the causes of earthquakes, controls on the size and timing of earthquakes, relation of the earthquake and Earth structure to the ground shaking that can damage buildings, and computer simulation techniques for modeling earthquakes and shaking. The 2019 Numerical Modeling of Earthquake Motions: Waves and Ruptures (NMEM19) workshop was the fifth in a series of similar workshops on this topic held at the same venue in previous years (2003, 2007, 2010, 2015). The central European location (Smolenice, Slovakia) brought together 76 participants from Europe, the US, and other countries. This award provided partial travel funding for the PI and 14 US participants (9 PhD students, 2 postdocs, 2 assistant professors, and 1 senior researcher). The 68 abstracts from the workshop were compiled in a Proceedings of the Workshop volume that is available to the public on the meeting website (http://www.nuquake.eu/NMEM2019/). Furthermore, presenters were encouraged to provide their presentation slides or posters to share with the general public, again on the meeting website, and most presenters opted to do this.

The workshop provided unique opportunities for discussion and development of scientific ideas related to earthquake processes and numerical modeling of earthquakes and seismic waves. A large portion of the workshop participants were PhD students, postdocs, and early career scientists. The small size of the workshop therefore facilitated direct and frequent interactions of senior scientists and experts in the field with these young researchers. An additional benefit of the workshop was sharing of recent scientific findings and recommended future directions for the community (e.g., as developed in the 2018 Modeling Earthquake Source Processes workshop in the US, which culminated in a white paper summarizing the state of the field and future directions) with the international scientific community.
